code: @Misc{,   title = {Balamuta Miscellaneous},   author = {James Balamuta},   howpublished = {R package (version 0.1.2)},   note = {GitHub repository: \url{https://github.com/coatless/jjb}},   url = {https://cran.r-project.org/package=jjb}, }

title: Balamuta Miscellaneous
text: goal jjb provide tools frequently used analyses. result, package contains large amount functions use day day analyses.

title: Balamuta Miscellaneous
text: jjb package available CRAN GitHub. CRAN version considered stable GitHub version state development may break. can install stable version jjb package : like living edge, feel free use copy development version :
code: install.packages("jjb") # Install remotes install.packages("remotes")  # Install the package from github remotes::install_github("coatless-rpkg/jjb")

title: Accuracy of the Model — acc
text: Calculates accuracy model taking mean number times truth, \(y\), equals predicted, \(\hat{y}\).

title: Accuracy of the Model — acc
text: y vector true \(y\) values yhat vector predicted \(\hat{y}\) values.

title: Accuracy of the Model — acc
text: accuracy classification numeric form.

title: Accuracy of the Model — acc
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(100)  # Generate data n = 1e2  y = round(runif(n)) yhat = round(runif(n))  # Compute o = acc(y, yhat)

Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols
title:
Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols
text: Convert Multiple Columns data.frame conversion data.frame current column types alternates.

title:
Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols

Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols
text: d data.frame needs specific columns converted. cast string vector containing either: "n" (numeric), "c" (character), "f" (factor).

title:
Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols
text: data.frame converted column types.

title:
Convert Multiple Columns of a data.frame

All at once conversion of a data.frame from current column types to
alternates. — convert_cols
code: n = 100  st = sample(LETTERS, n, replace = TRUE) sr = sample(letters, n, replace = TRUE) num = rnorm(n)  d = data.frame(x = st, y = num, z = sr, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  # Convert all columns  o = convert_cols(d,c("f", "c", "f"))  # Convert a subset d[, c(1, 3)] = convert_cols(d[, c(1, 3)], c("f", "f"))

Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: Scale features datasets.

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
code: feature_rescale(x, x_min = NULL, x_max = NULL)  feature_derescale(x_rescaled, x_min, x_max)  feature_norm(x, x_norm = NULL)  feature_denorm(x_norm_std, x_norm = NULL)  feature_standardize(x, x_mean = NULL, x_sd = NULL)  feature_destandardize(x_std, x_mean = NULL, x_sd = NULL)

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: x Numeric values x_min Minimum non-normalized numeric value x_max Maximum non-normalized numeric value x_rescaled Rescaled values x. x_norm Euclidean norm x x_norm_std Euclidean vector normalized x values. x_mean Mean x values x_sd Standard Deviation x values x_std Z-transformed x values

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: numeric vector.

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: following functions provide means either scale features descale features return normal. functions ideal working optimizers.

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: Convert original data \(x\) \(x_{scaled}\): $$x[scaled] = (x-x[min])/(x[max]-x[min])$$ move rescaled value \(x_{scaled}\) original value \(x\) use: $$x = x[scaled] * (x[max] - x[min]) + x[min]$$

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: Convert original data \(x\) \(x_{std}\): $$x[std] = (x-avg[x])/(sigma[x])$$ move standardized value \(x_{std}\) original value \(x\) use: $$x = x[std] * sigma[x] + avg[x]$$

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: Convert original data \(x\) \(x_{norm}\): $$x[norm] = (x)/||x||$$ move normalized value \(x_{norm}\) original value \(x\) use: $$x = x[norm] * ||x||$$

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
text: James Balamuta

title: Feature Scaling — feature_scaling
code: # Rescaling Features temperatures = c(94.2, 88.1, 32, 0)  temp_min = min(temperatures) temp_max = max(temperatures)  temperatures_norm   = feature_rescale(temp_min, temp_max) temperatures_denorm = feature_derescale(temperatures_norm, temp_min, temp_max)  all.equal(temperatures, temperatures_denorm) #> [1] "Numeric: lengths (4, 1) differ"   # Norming Features x = 1:10  x_norm = sqrt(sum(x^2))  x_norm_std = feature_norm(x, x_norm)  x_recover = feature_denorm(x_norm_std, x_norm) all.equal(x, x_recover) #> [1] TRUE  # Standardizing Features x      = 1:10  x_mean = mean(x) x_sd   = sd(x)  x_std  = feature_standardize(x, x_mean, x_sd) x_recovery = feature_destandardize(x, x_mean, x_sd)  all.equal(x, x_recovery) #> [1] "Mean relative difference: 3.02765"

what: Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
title: Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
text: Determine floor cap numeric variable taking quantiles. Using quantiles, values data found lower higher floor cap replaced.

title: Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
text: x vector length \(N\). probs vector containing two values 0 1, first less second.

title: Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
text: vector values floored capped.

title: Floor and Cap a Numeric Variable — floor_and_cap
code: # One case version n = 100  x = rnorm(n)  x[n - 1] = -99999 x[n] = 10000  y = floor_and_cap(x)  # Dataset example  d = data.frame(x, y = rnorm(n))  o = sapply(d, floor_and_cap)

code: is_whole(2.3) #> [1] FALSE is_whole(4) #> [1] TRUE is_whole(c(1,2,3)) #> [1] TRUE is_whole(c(.4,.5,.6)) #> [1] FALSE is_whole(c(7,.8,9)) #> [1] FALSE

title: jjb: Balamuta Miscellaneous — jjb-package
text: Set common functions used manipulating colors, detecting interacting 'RStudio', modeling, formatting, determining users' operating system, feature scaling, !

what: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
title: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
text: Obtain Maximum Minimum n elements vector.

title: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
text: x Data vector n Number observations select

title: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
text: vector containing maximum/minimum \(n\) elements.

title: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
text: underlying function sorts data using base::sort() extracts appropriate n-back n-forward values. result sorting procedure, inefficient function.

title: Maxima and Minima n elements — max_n
code: x = 1:10  # Defaults to traditional max # This is more costly to compute than using the regular max function. max_n(x)  #> [1] 10  # Retrieve top two observations (highest first) max_n(x, 2) #> [1] 10  9  # Missing values have no effect on the sorting procedure x[9] = NA max_n(x, 3) #> [1] 10  8  7  # Defaults to traditional min. # This is more costly to compute than using the regular min function. min_n(x) #> [1] 1 min(x) #> [1] NA  # Retrieve bottom two observations (lowest first) min_n(x, 2) #> [1] 1 2  # Missing values have no effect on the sorting procedure x[2] = NA min_n(x, 3) #> [1] 1 3 4

title: Mean Squared Error (MSE) — mse
text: Calculates mean square model taking mean sum squares truth, \(y\), predicted, \(\hat{y}\) observation \(\).

title: Mean Squared Error (MSE) — mse
text: y vector true \(y\) values yhat vector predicted \(\hat{y}\) values.

title: Mean Squared Error (MSE) — mse
text: MSE numeric form.

title: Mean Squared Error (MSE) — mse
text: equation MSE : $$\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{= 1}^n {{{\left( {{y_i} - {{\hat y}_i}} \right)}^2}}$$

title: Mean Squared Error (MSE) — mse
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(100)  # Generate data n = 1e2  y = rnorm(n) yhat = rnorm(n, 0.5)  # Compute o = mse(y, yhat)

what: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
title: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
text: Computes proportion data missing given data set.

title: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
code: na_prop_overall(x)  na_prop_by_variable(x)  na_prop_by_observation(x)  na_count_overall(x)  na_count_by_variable(x)  na_count_by_observation(x)

title: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
text: x vector length \(N\) matrix dimensions \(N \times P\).

title: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
text: Overall: single numeric value [0, 1] count [0, N]. Variable: \(P\) different numeric values [0, 1] counts [0, N]. Observation: \(N\) different numeric values [0, 1] counts [0, P].

title: Determine Amount of Missing Values in Data — na_prop_overall
code: # By vector x = c(1, 2, NA, 4) na_prop_overall(x) #> [1] 0.25 na_count_overall(x) #> [1] 1  # By Data Frame missing_df = data.frame(  a = c(1, 2, NA, 4),  b = c(3, NA, 2, NA) )  # Proportion na_prop_overall(missing_df) #> [1] 0.375 na_prop_by_variable(missing_df) #>    a    b  #> 0.25 0.50  na_prop_by_observation(missing_df) #> [1] 0.0 0.5 0.5 0.5  # Counts na_count_overall(missing_df) #> [1] 3 na_count_by_variable(missing_df) #> a b  #> 1 2  na_count_by_observation(missing_df) #> [1] 0 1 1 1

title: Pad Numeric Numbers — pad_number
code: # Padding applied pad_number(8:10) #> [1] "08" "09" "10"  # No padding applied pad_number(2:3) #> [1] "2" "3"  # Pads non-negative number with 0. # This needs to be improved slightly... pad_number(-1:1) #> [1] "-1" "00" "01"

title: Convert RGB Value to Hexadecimal — rgb_to_hex
Convert RGB Value to Hexadecimal — rgb_to_hex
text: R int 0 255 Red value. G int 0 255 Green value. B int 0 255 Blue value. pound bool indicates whether pound sign prepended hexadecimal.

title: Convert RGB Value to Hexadecimal — rgb_to_hex
text: string containing hexadecimal information.

title: Convert RGB Value to Hexadecimal — rgb_to_hex
code: # Hexadecimal with pound sign rgb_to_hex(255,255,255) #> [1] "#000000"  # Heaxadecimal without pound sign rgb_to_hex(255,255,255,FALSE) #> [1] "000000"

title: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: Calculates root mean square model taking square root mean sum squares truth, \(y\), predicted, \(\hat{y}\) observation \(\).

title: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: y vector true \(y\) values yhat vector predicted \(\hat{y}\) values.

title: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: RMSE numeric form

title: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: formula RMSE : $$\sqrt {\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{= 1}^n {{{\left( {{y_i} - {{\hat y}_i}} \right)}^2}} } $$

title: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(100)  # Generate data n = 1e2  y = rnorm(n) yhat = rnorm(n, 0.5)  # Compute o = mse(y, yhat)
